results.name: Primorial base expansion of n converted into its prime product form, but with 1 subtracted from all nonzero digits: a(n) = A003557(A276086(n)).
link: Antti Karttunen, Table of n, a(n) for n = 0..2310
Antti Karttunen, Data supplement: n, a(n) computed for n = 0..32768
Index entries for sequences related to primorial base
mathematica: Block[{b = MixedRadix[Reverse@ Prime@ Range@ 12]}, Array[#1/(Times @@ #2[[All, 1]]) & @@ {#1, FactorInteger[#]} &[Times @@ Power @@@ #] &@ Transpose@ {Prime@ Range@ Length@ #, Reverse@ #} &@ IntegerDigits[#, b] &, 87, 0]] (* _Michael De Vlieger_, Mar 12 2021 *)
program: (PARI) A328572(n) = { my(m=1, p=2); while(n, if(n%p, m *= p^((n%p)-1)); n = n\p; p = nextprime(1+p)); (m); };
results.author: _Antti Karttunen_, Oct 20 2019
